segments.text: Administration of an institution.
From the inside.
Mr Rudder was still president in those years.
And I was able to.
Increase I was able to see his leadership qualities.
Close up.
One of my primary tasks was to review all masters and doctoral thesis proposals.
That service broadened my understanding and introduced me to a broader variety of scholars
and their research techniques.
I literally read the proposals and often offered suggestions for improvement.
Similarly, I appointed the graduate council representatives on all doctoral committees and used the technique of marking
each appointees name in the graduate catalog and trying to select individuals from all across the campus to serve on doctoral programs in a discipline far removed from theirs.
A task in which they were expected to report
to Dr. Hall regarding the appropriate quality and thoroughness of the candidate's examination, preliminary and final examinations
as well as the dissertation.
When I appointed myself to one of those committees, I soon developed a pair of standard questions to ask the candidate while I watched the members
of the committee who were from the student's major department.
One of the questions was to inquire, quote, if you had known at the time you began your graduate studies all that you know now about the quality of the programs in your area of specialization.

to what institutions would you have applied for admission other than Texas A&M and why would you have been interested in those programs or in other words what are the outstanding programs in your specialty period quote the other question
was directed at learning the student's acquaintance with the areas of publication in the specialty.
So there I asked, quote, in order to obtain the highest
scholarly acclaim and benefit for your scholarly reputation, to what journal will you send perhaps a chapter of your dissertation?
For public journal or journals, will you send portions of your dissertation
And to what press, either profit-making or university-related, will you send the manuscript in the hope that they will accept it as a book?"
One day, after I served
I believe a year and a half, Bill Barzac told me that one day after coffee that he thought he was going to resign his position and go back to English.
That administration quote really wasn't his cup of tea, period quote.
That afternoon, Dr. Hall invited me in and then inquired about my interest
in serving as the associate dean of the graduate school on a full-time basis.
I responded by asking him if there was any plan in the future to select a full-time dean of the graduate school
since he was serving as both Vice President of Academic Affairs and Graduate Dean.
When he responded that he thought that might happen within a year, I was encouraged, but continued with the inquiry
About whether or not quote anyone.
From liberal arts.
Would be considered for that position.
Period quote.
My hopes were dashed when he indicate when he.
Told me that.
There had already been a decision made.
But the new graduate Dean would come from agriculture.
So I told him I should not, I did not want to remain in the subordinate position.
George Kunze was soon announced as the new graduate dean, and Dr. Hall asked me if I would stay for a year to work with Dr. Kunze, which I did, and from which
I benefited in terms of experience greatly.
Paragraph.
So it was an old friend who called me one afternoon in the fall of 1970 to ask if I was acquainted with Jack McKinney Williams
a Southern historian who had gotten his PhD at Emory University in Atlanta, who had just been selected as president of Texas A&M University.
I told him that I knew who Dr. Williams was and that possibly we had shaken hands a time or two at the Southern Historical Association Convention, but that I did not know him well.
except to have heard very positive things about Dr. Williams, both as a historian and a leader of Texas higher education during his days as commissioner.
Paragraph, the next step in life-changing events came soon after Dr. Williams arrived

When I read a note, a brief note from the new president, which informed me that one of the last things that he had done before leaving Knoxville was to chat with his doctoral dissertation advisor, Bell Wiley.
who had been one of our advisory editors with the Jeff Davis Project and whom I knew as one of the finest historians and friends I would ever meet.
The note from Dr. Williams informed me that Dr. Wiley had told him that when he got to College Station,

if he, quote, wanted to talk to a faculty member who seemed well acquainted all across the campus and might be a source for information about the faculty and their goals, that he should talk with Haskell Munroe.
period quote.
Thus, Dr. Williams asked me to call his secretary, Nelda, and come over for a visit.
When I called that always reliable, careful, and caring lady, she gave me an appointment at 4.45 in the afternoon, which I thought
was a hint at a brief and comparatively meaningless chat.
That expectation was forever erased when we finished our delightful visit
At least two hours after it began.
As I was about to walk out the doorway, Doctor Williams put his hand on my shoulder.
And asked me if I would quote ever be interested.
In serving as a member of the A&M administration period quote.
Without much.
Preparation.
I responded.
But I had not mentioned it to anybody else, but that yes, I thought I would.
Meanwhile.
More changes were underway.
Because Jack Williams.
came with broad academic experience and insight and was able to build a lofty structure, a lofty institutional structure on the strong and solid foundation which only Earl Rudder could have built.
In hindsight, the Rudder Williams years became Camelot on the brasses.
Only Earl Rudder could have done what he did.
And only Jack Williams could have done what he did.
Neither could have accomplished the other's victories.
And both were uniquely prepared for their time and place.
Jack Williams had marvelous personal qualities as a speaker, as a public speaker,
An individual with.
Strong connections.
In Austin and in Washington.
Especially with the federal.
Agencies relating to our education.
His record of assisting.
The separate the.
Historically black.
Land-grant schools in the South.
was little known but truly important.
Also during those years the president of Texas A&M was also the president of the A&M system.
Thus there was no contention in almost all of Mr. Rutter's years and
William's time until 1976 over where the experiment stations and extension services, other state agencies reported.
There was one chief executive officer and everyone knew it.
Horace Byers had replaced Wayne Hall as Vice President for Academic Affairs.
Dr. Byers, a nationally and internationally known scholar in the geosciences, came from the University of Chicago and increased the pace of progress which Wayne Hall had begun.
He retired not long after
Dr. Williams' arrival and was replaced by John C. Calhoun, Jr., a marvelously skillful leader with truly unique capability.
A native of Pennsylvania, Dr. Calhoun

had begun his studies at what was then the Pennsylvania State College in petroleum engineering and soon after completion of his doctoral studies earned worldwide recognition as a truly innovative and creative thinker regarding
oil regarding petroleum location, exploration, and recovery.
He had come to A&M in the 1950s as dean of engineering, had served in the Kennedy administration as science advisor to the Secretary of Interior,
And thus he too brought broad scope to the administration.
All of that began to link to me.
And near the end of 19...
71 and the beginning of 1972.
That first year of Dr. Williams had been marked by a change, by an enormous increase in enrollment of coeds because he had
informed the board of directors that he would not accept their invitation to come to College Station as president of A&M unless they would allow him to create a woman's dormitory.
When they assured him they would back his selection of an architect,
And planning to build such a structure.
He noted that he wanted them to approve his identification.
As he began.
His service on November 1, 1970.
Have a an existing dormitory.
To be reserved for women only.
when the spring semester began in 1971.
As word of that decision spread, women filled that dormitory and everyone became aware that there were no hindrances to women's enrollment at A&M in any manner.
Almost exactly a year later, I came to my office in Nagel Hall after returning from North Carolina with Joe and our children.
Among the notes in my box was a request that I return a phone call to the office of Vice President Calhoun.
A gentleman with whom I had little, if any, personal acquaintance.
The secretary.
responded to my call by indicating that Dr Calhoun had been trying without success to reach me for a number of days.
She accepted my explanation of the absence when I told her that we had been in North Carolina
because of my wife's stepfather's death and burial, and then remained for Christmas there with her mother.
She indicated that Dr. Calhoun wanted to speak to me as soon as I could come over, so I asked what was the nature of his concern.
With obvious, with a bit of awkwardness, she noted that she was unaware of the reason for his concern and that usually he informed her regarding
the nature of important calls.
So as I walked to the Teague building on the east end of the campus, I wondered what the vice president of academic affairs might ask me to do.
Much to my surprise, he invited me to join his staff with the title Assistant Vice President for Academic Affairs.
In that position, I would join him and the Associate Vice President, Dr. Richard E. Winerdi, W-A-I-N-E-R-D-I, a marvelously talented and always energetic
member of the petroleum engineering faculty who had studied with Dr. Calhoun first at the University of Oklahoma and then completed his doctoral work with Calhoun back at Penn State.
I asked Dr. Calhoun about my
role.
For example, did he want me to be particularly responsible for reviewing matters from the humanities, social sciences, business, education areas?
He quickly explained that no, that instead of dividing
the task up that way, the three of us would be a team working on all tasks together.
I asked him if I could continue to teach a survey course.
And he smiled, adding, of course, if you would like to do so, but we cannot give you extra compensation for that effort.
Thus, I continued the plan to teach every semester and could begin to honestly state that my compensation for that teaching was in my heart, not my hip pocket.
That service began January of 1942.
and allowed me to learn a broad view of all campus efforts.
Teaching, research, service, committees, coordinating board, relation to
former students, the general public, the legislature, public affairs, athletics, fundraising, and student leadership.
For anyone who would later serve as a campus-wide administrator,
working with John Calhoun was the most important and valuable preparation that anyone could have.
And now, as I am on Deacon Drive, a block and a half from the house, we will terminate this part of this analysis.
